day1.title: Labeling the phone as object
day1.description: Today, you'll learn to see your phone for what it really is—just an object, not an extension of yourself.

cards.title: Labeling the phone as object
cards.content: Today, you'll learn to see your phone for what it really is—just an object, not an extension of yourself.

cards.title: How it works
cards.content: Throughout the day, we'll send you gentle reminders to notice your phone as a physical object. When you pick it up, feel its weight. Notice its edges. See it as a tool, not a companion.

cards.title: Reminders
cards.content: We'll send you 3-4 mindful moments today. Each one takes just 10 seconds—a brief pause to recenter.

cards.title: Why this works
cards.content: When we label our phones as objects, we break the emotional attachment. Research shows that creating cognitive distance from our devices reduces compulsive checking by up to 40%.

cards.title: Bathroom Break
cards.content: Our phones feel like extensions of ourselves, which is why it's important to remember what it's like to be physically away from them. Your bathroom is the easiest place to start.

cards.title: How it works
cards.content: Today, make an effort to leave your phone outside of the door every time you enter your bathroom. If you forget, don't beat yourself up, just try to remember for next time. We'll send you some reminders throughout the day.

cards.title: Reminders
cards.content: We'll remind you throughout the day to leave your phone outside when using the bathroom.

cards.title: Why this works
cards.content: When you pair your phone with routine habits, it strengthens compulsive & mindless use. By making your bathroom a phone-free space, you'll start to gain insight into this pattern—the first step to breaking it.

day3.title: One Word Check-In
day3.description: Start to identify how your phone makes you feel.

cards.title: One Word Check-In
cards.content: Today, you'll begin your journey by identifying the emotions that drive compulsive phone use.

cards.title: How it works
cards.content: When you pick up your phone throughout the day, try saying one word out loud to describe your emotional state before you begin using it. Don't force it; just do it whenever you remember to.

cards.title: Example
cards.content: If you're bored during work, for example, and find yourself opening Instagram, simply say "bored" out loud. You can also try doing it while already using your phone, or after you lock it—whatever feels most natural.

cards.title: Why this works
cards.content: Most of the time, you check your phone automatically, without noticing the emotions driving the behavior. By naming a feeling out loud, even once a day, you build what's called affect labeling, a proven technique that increases self-awareness and reduces compulsive patterns.
